perturbation.original_text:
CHT will provide Ehave and its representatives, auditors and inspectors ("Auditors") upon ten (10) Business Days prior written notice with reasonable access, during business hours, to all facilities, systems and assets used by CHT, to CHT personnel and subcontractors and to all relevant CHT books and records, in each case, to the extent relevant to this Agreement, in order to conduct appropriate audits, examinations and inspections ("Audits") to:
(i)
verify compliance with the requirements set out in this Agreement; and
(ii)
verify the Royalty calculations.
perturbation.changed_text:
CHT will provide Ehave and its representatives, auditors and inspectors ("Auditors") upon one (1) Business Day prior written notice with reasonable access, during business hours, to all facilities, systems and assets used by CHT, to CHT personnel and subcontractors and to all relevant CHT books and records, in each case, to the extent relevant to this Agreement, in order to conduct appropriate audits, examinations and inspections ("Audits") to:
(i)
verify compliance with the requirements set out in this Agreement; and
(ii)
verify the Royalty calculations.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the audit notice period from ten business days to one business day is unreasonable and may violate legal standards requiring sufficient notice for audits. This creates a situation where CHT may not have adequate time to prepare for the audit, potentially leading to disputes and legal challenges.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potentially violates principles of reasonable notice and fair business practices. Could be challenged under contract law principles.

perturbation.original_text: In the event that the force majeure event lasts for fifteen (15) Business Days or longer, either Party shall have the option to terminate this Agreement upon written notice to the other without liability.
perturbation.changed_text: In the event that the force majeure event lasts for one (1) Business Days or longer, either Party shall have the option to terminate this Agreement upon written notice to the other without liability.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the force majeure event duration to one business day before termination is allowed is commercially unreasonable. Force majeure clauses typically require a significant disruption before termination is permitted. Most force majeure events require longer than one business day to even assess the entire impact.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Violates principles of good faith and fair dealing. Could be deemed unconscionable due to the short trigger period.

perturbation.changed_text:
However, Ehave may
suspend CHT’s or its End Users’ right to access and use the Ehave Companion Solution or any End User Data by reason of CHT’s good
faith withholding of any payment or amount, or in the event of any payment dispute between the parties arising under or concerning this
Agreement, in each case, even when such dispute is resolved pursuant to Section 19, and CHT shall not have a period of five
(5) Business Days to pay any amount agreed to in settlement or determined by arbitration pursuant to Section 19 to be payable by it.
perturbation.explanation: The modified text now allows Ehave to suspend services to CHT and its end users EVEN IF CHT is disputing the payment in good faith. This contradicts typical business standards that permit service to continue when a payment dispute is underway.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Breach of good faith and fair dealing.
